Now these mistaken beliefs manifest as a {@creature planar incarnate|MPP} (see {@book Morte's Planar Parade|MPP}) of a plane that doesn't exist: a Fiend-overrun version of the Outlands (use the planar incarnate's Fiend form). The planar incarnate is hostile toward non-modrons. The round after appearing, it attacks the characters and fights until destroyed.

entries.name: Replacement Data
entries: As the planar incarnate is a manifestation of {@creature X01|ToFW}'s beliefs, those beliefs can be undermined. A character can present to {@creature X01|ToFW} evidence that the Outlands aren't overrun by Fiends, such as mementos they picked up in the gate-towns or recordings from the Mosaic Mimir. If a character uses an action to present such information and succeeds on a DC 18 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, the planar incarnate has disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws until the start of the character's next turn.

entries.name: Lost Data
entries: Once the planar incarnate is destroyed, {@creature X01|ToFW} collapses. A character with proficiency in Intelligence ({@skill Arcana} or {@skill Medicine}) can tell the following:

items: {@creature X01|ToFW} is alive, but its mind is vacant.
To reactivate, {@creature X01|ToFW} would need to recover its knowledge about the planes.

entries: The Mosaic Mimir has the information {@creature X01|ToFW} needs to reactivate. The characters might come to this conclusion on their own, or a character who investigates {@creature X01|ToFW}'s body might realize that within the damaged panel is enough room for the {@item mimir|SatO}. If a character inserts the {@item mimir|SatO} into {@creature X01|ToFW}, the hexton reactivates a moment later. This has multiple effects, which are summarized in the following sections.

entries.title: The distorted beliefs of the hexton modron {@creature X01|ToFW} and its wayward followers manifest as a godlike incarnation of a nonexistent realm

entries.name: Reactivating X01

entries.title: In one possible reality, modrons enter the fray in the endless Blood War between demons and devils

entries: Should the characters reactivate {@creature X01|ToFW} by embedding their {@item mimir|SatO} in the modron leader, {@creature X01|ToFW}'s perspective on the Outlands shifts. This view rapidly disseminates among the other modrons trapped in Tyrant's Spiral. What this perspective is depends on what information the characters recorded in their {@item mimir|SatO} during {@adventure part 2|ToFW|2} and whether their reports on the Outlands were accurate, inconsistent, or skewed. Consult the Mimir Restoration Tracker from {@adventure chapter 4|ToFW|2|Chapter 4–Into the Outlands}, and choose which of the following sections best matches the information the character recorded in their {@item mimir|SatO}. Each entry details the data's effects on {@creature X01|ToFW}'s personality and has ramifications in the "{@adventure Conclusion|ToFW|3|Conclusion}" section.

entries.name: Accurate
entries: If the characters' {@item mimir|SatO} largely details the Outlands in an unbiased way, {@creature X01|ToFW} realizes reality is behaving within expected parameters. It reactivates as a calm, logical modron that is eager to lead its followers directly to Mechanus, where they can make an unremarkable report.

entries.name: Inconsistent
entries: If the characters provided inconsistent details about the Outlands—several accurate and several skewed—{@creature X01|ToFW} reactivates and exhibits dramatic mood swings. It seeks to lead the modrons to its home plane, but it is uncertain where that is.

entries.name: Skewed
entries: If the characters' reports on the Outlands reflect their bias for a particular philosophy or alignment, the modrons act in opposition. The Skewed Data Results table notes {@creature X01|ToFW}'s personality after being influenced by data skewed along the lines of particular alignments. If the information characters provided to their {@item mimir|SatO} strongly reflects the philosophies of a faction in Sigil, choose the result that best corresponds with that faction's agenda.

entries.caption: Skewed Data Results
rows: Rigid, even for a modron, and insistent that the characters aid it in returning to Mechanus
Serene and overly concerned about the characters' safety
Manipulative and eager to abandon the characters and the other modrons after it escapes

entries.name: Escaping Tyrant's Spiral
entries: If {@creature X01|ToFW} is reactivated, the modron wants to escape Tyrant's Spiral, but it doesn't know about the portals in the nearby areas. Characters might use the methods here to help the modrons escape.

entries.name: Portal to Hopeless
entries: The portal to {@book Hopeless|SatO|3|Hopeless} in {@adventure area T3|ToFW|3|T3: Ocular Space} is narrow and a challenge for the modrons to reach. It will take days for all the modrons to pass through, and likely many portal-key tears to keep the portal open. {@creature Beholder||Beholders} also frequent this area and try to pick off modrons as they escape.

entries.name: Portal to Sigil
entries: The portal in {@adventure area T1|ToFW|3|T1: Lair of the Eye}, which the characters used to enter Tyrant's Spiral, still functions. However, like the portal to Hopeless, it is difficult to reach. Additionally, unleashing thousands of modrons on Sigil is dangerous. Should this happen, the Lady of Pain intervenes quickly and, through a {@creature dabus|MPP}, informs the characters they have 10 minutes to set things right. How the characters can reconcile this—and avoid the Mazes—is up to you.

entries.name: Portal to Xaos
entries: The portal in {@adventure area T5|ToFW|3|T5: Gzemnid's Maw} opens only when Gzemnid pleases. Characters can convince the beholder god to let the modrons pass, but Gzemnid demands to consume half the modrons first. A character can convince Gzemnid to eat only a quarter of the modrons by succeeding on a DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, or they might bribe Gzemnid with the promise of bringing it a more tempting meal—for example, it has always wanted to eat a dragon or another god.

entries.name: Remarkable Escape
entries: It would take hundreds of castings of spells like {@spell gate} or {@spell teleportation circle} to relocate all the modrons. You might allow the characters to develop outlandish schemes or entreat otherworldly beings to help the modrons escape. Debts and ramifications accrued here can provide springboards to future adventures.

entries.name: Abandonment or Sacrifice
entries: The characters can leave the modrons in Tyrant's Spiral, but eventually Shemeshka or another being will manipulate the modrons to their own ends. If the characters try to destroy the modrons en masse, {@creature X01|ToFW} commands the modrons to defend themselves. Although annihilating the modrons would maintain the equilibrium of the planes, doing so might have ramifications on characters' alignments.

entries.name: Conclusion
entries: If the characters release {@creature X01|ToFW} and the modrons from Tyrant's Spiral, their work for {@creature R04M|ToFW} is complete, but the ramifications for the multiverse might be dire.

entries.name: Realigning the Multiverse
entries: How the characters contend with the lost modrons has far-rippling effects on the multiverse. The data from the characters' {@item mimir|SatO} affects not just {@creature X01|ToFW}'s perspective but also those of thousands of modrons. If the modrons return home, this data influences the cosmic alignment of Mechanus. Countless modrons across the multiverse then seek to rebalance the planes in accordance with the new arrangement of the plane of absolute law.

Depending on how the characters' {@item mimir|SatO} affected the liberated modrons, the axiomatic beings affect the multiverse in one of the following ways. Choose whichever one corresponds with the result from the "{@adventure Reactivating X01|ToFW|3|Reactivating X01}" section. This determines how the characters' actions and the released modrons affect the planes.

entries.name: Accurate
entries: On returning to their home plane, the modrons report their data, which results in incremental refinements to Mechanus's workings. No precipitable changes to the status quo of the multiverse occur. No other creatures suffer the multiversal glitch the characters experienced.

entries.name: Inconsistent
entries: Unless the characters intervene, it takes months for {@creature X01|ToFW} and a much-diminished group of modrons to return to Mechanus. When they do, chaos ensues. Modrons behave strangely across the planes, and chaotic creatures like slaadi operate unopposed. Numerous creatures experience the multiversal glitch that affected the characters. Ultimately, the modron leader, Primus, initiates a new Great Modron March to correct the chaos sweeping the planes.

entries.name: Skewed
entries: On the modrons' return to Mechanus, the skewed data in the characters' {@item mimir|SatO} causes all modrons across the planes to react differently toward different philosophies or types of beings. The Multiversal Effects of Skewed Data table summarizes the new behavior of the vast majority of modrons.

entries.caption: Multiversal Effects of Skewed Data
rows: Modrons more vigorously oppose chaotic beings; modrons become more hostile against chaotic beings and expressions of lawlessness.
Modrons oppose evil beings; Celestials ally with modrons to crusade against evil across the planes.
Modrons oppose good beings; Fiends manipulate modrons to besiege bastions of good across the planes.
Modrons withdraw to Mechanus; chaotic beings act unopposed across the planes.

entries.name: Unity of Rings
entries: Once the characters have dealt with the modrons and escaped Tyrant's Spiral, they're free to go where they please. If they find themselves in the Outlands and seek to return to Sigil, they can find a portal to the city near the closest gate-town. This portal opens within sight of the Mortuary.
Back in Sigil, the characters might seek out any of the following parties.

entries.name: Farrow or Other Sigil Contacts
entries: {@creature Farrow|ToFW} or another Sigil-based ally is glad to hear the characters resolved the strangeness plaguing them. The ally is well connected and know others who need accomplished adventurers. The ally also knows of useful portals, including those to Material Plane worlds the characters might hail from. Use this ally to lead the characters to future adventures.

entries.name: R04M
entries: Depending on how the characters resolved the situation in Tyrant's Spiral, {@creature R04M|ToFW} might be pleased or horrified. Nevertheless, if the characters helped any of the modrons escape, {@creature R04M|ToFW} rewards them with the promised gems. This includes gems worth 15,013 gp as well as an {@item Elemental Gem, Emerald||elemental gem (emerald)} and a resin-encrusted {@item ring of regeneration}.

If the modron remains on good terms with the characters, {@creature R04M|ToFW} might seek to join them and see more of the multiverse. Or, if the characters have skewed the planes in some way, {@creature R04M|ToFW} might seek to set things right, perhaps by pursuing multiversal secrets within the Spire.

entries.name: Shemeshka
entries: The arcanaloth is frustrated by the characters' interfering with her plot and avoids them for a time, but she isn't one to let annoyance get in the way of opportunity. Shemeshka might eventually contact the characters to involve them in future schemes.

Shemeshka might contact the characters sooner if the data in their {@item mimir|SatO} skewed toward evil, as it's possible the characters produced the results she was seeking. If they did, the arcanaloth enjoys increased business selling weapons to demons, devils, and modrons embroiled in the Blood War. Shemeshka sends the characters polite thank-you notes, each with a complimentary platinum casino chip and an invitation to visit Fortune's Wheel anytime.

entries.name: Sigil Factions
entries: A character who reports their exploits to a Sigil faction they're a member of gains the attention of their faction's leaders. If the characters' {@item mimir|SatO} changed the multiverse in a way that their faction is in favor of or opposed to, a character's faction leader might have work for the party, either capitalizing on changes to reality or seeking to set things right.

entries.name: The Lady's Gift
entries: After the characters have attended to any immediate business in Sigil, read or paraphrase the following text when next they're traveling together in the city:

It's unclear when or how it happened, but the street around you is empty and still. Before you can ponder the cosmically infinitesimal chances of a Sigil street emptying, a somber, gray-skinned figure floats into your path. The dabus hovers silently as a string of illusory images fade in to view around it. Prominent among these symbols is the razored image of the Lady of Pain.
The first character to succeed on a DC 10 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check deciphers the dabus's message. It reads as follows:
The Lady saw what you did. She has a message: stay out of trouble.
Once the message is deciphered, the dabus points at the door of an empty building nearby and then floats away. If a character opens the door, read or paraphrase the following text:

The rickety plank door opens easily, revealing a wall of crusty bricks and gnarled razorvine. Embedded at the wall's center is a perfectly square, metallic brick with a faintly glowing towerlike rune on its surface.

The glowing brick is a {@item cubic gate}, which slips from the wall effortlessly. The magic item is keyed to this door in Sigil, a door in the characters' walking castle on the Outlands, a world on the Material Plane, and three other planes of your choice.
As the cube is removed, the brick wall transforms into the glowing arch of an active portal that leads anywhere you choose.
The adventure ends here, with the characters on the threshold of the multiverse—a place every bit as unpredictable and dangerous as it has always been.
"What happens next? Just see where your imagination leads. I find that's where all good things start."
